worklogs.comment:
rjzamora commented on pull request #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361
 
 
   This is a WIP PR to address [ARROW-5349](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-5349).  From the python side, this exposes a `file_path` keyword argument to `write_table`.  The string is then used to populate file-path metadata for each column-chunk written.  
   
   Here is a simple example:
   
   ```p
   import os
   import pandas as pd
   import pyarrow.parquet as pq
   import pyarrow as pa
   
   df = pd.DataFrame({'a': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'], 'b': [1, 2, 3, 4]})
   table = pa.Table.from_pandas(df)
   
   metadata_list = []
   path = "./smalldataset"; os.system('mkdir ' + path)
   filename = path + "/part.0.parquet.dbg"
   with open(filename, "wb") as f:
       pq.write_table(
           table,
           f,
           file_path=filename,
           metadata_collector=metadata_list
       )
   meta = metadata_list[0].to_dict()
   print(meta['row_groups'][0]['columns'][0]['file_path'])
   ```
   Output: `./smalldataset/part.0.parquet.dbg`
   
   This is a WIP - Please provide suggestions for cleaner solutions, etc.  Note that my C++ background is somewhat limited :)
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on issue #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494456335
 
 
   hi @rjzamora I would prefer a solution that doesn't involve touching so many APIs. In my comment on ARROW-5349, I wrote "I would recommend adding a method on parquet::ParquetFileWriter that will set this attribute to a particular value for all column chunk metadata created. This method can be exposed then in Python". What do you think about this solution? This requires one new API endpoint in `parquet::arrow::FileWriter` and one new API in `ParquetFileWriter`, otherwise APIs are unchanged.

   Thanks for the quick response @wesm - I completely agree that too many API's are touched.  Sorry I veered away from your suggestion, but I was having trouble figuring out an elegant way to utilize the `ColumnChunkMetaDataBuilder::set_file_path` API...   I am pretty confident that I can work out a much better solution
   
   With that said, it is not immediately obvious to me how to modify the file-path metadata without adding additional methods (or modifying others) beyond the two APIs you mentioned.  I will take a closer look and follow up - Thanks again!

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494706396
 
 
   One remark on the actual functionality: this currently sets the file path both for the metadata written into the file itself, as for the metadata returned (appended to `metadata_collector`). 
   I am not fully sure this is the desired behaviour (although it does not give problems when reading it back in, it seems, not sure if this file path is actually used currently in parquet-cpp). I don't know the parquet "common practices" well enough for that, but it is in any case not what fastparquet does, and we should probably check hive or spark that generate / read such datasets.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494808575
 
 
   In the parquet-cpp implementation, we currently indeed do not make use of `file_path` when reading, so setting it does not have any effect. 
   But are we sure that it is the same for other implementation? (just a question, I have no idea)
   
   The thrift description is quite clear it should not be set and that the path should be relative to the file (which is also not true here): "File where column data is stored.  If not set, assumed to be same file as metadata.  This path is relative to the current file."

   ```
   $UUID.parquet
   _metadata
   ```
   
   The file_path in both cases is `$UUID.parquet`. So I think there is no conflict because the column data is in that file.

   But once you have a nested dataset like
   
   ```
   A=0/
       $UUID.parquet
   A=1/
       $UUID.parquet
   _metadata
   ```
   
   then the file_path would be `A=0/$UUID.parquet`, in which this would be wrong if it is inside the file itself?

rjzamora commented on issue #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494950617
 
 
   I don't think there is anything wrong with setting the `file_path` in the footer metadata when there is a single file, or when all files are in the same directory.  To obey the thrift defintion of `file_path`, the value should just be the file name (without the path).  There would also be no problem in general if the `file_path` corresponded to the absolute path of the data (which was my mistaken assumption when I prepared this PR).  
   
   Unfortunately, if `file_path` corresponds to a relative path, then the hypothetical example shared by @jorisvandenbossche is an obvious problem, because the footer would need to have a different value than the standalone metadata file (`_metadata`).  It seems that this kind of nested file structure should be supported, so I think that this example disqualifies the solution I have implemented so far.
   
   Perhaps it is necessary to add a new C++ API (exposed in python) to modify the contents of an existing metadata object?  My understanding of the current arrow-parquet implementation is that a `FileMetaData` object becomes immutable once it is created.  There is a good chance that my understanding is wrong here,  but I am not seeing a straightforward way to modify the `ColumnChunkMetaData` after the fact. 
   
   
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

martindurant commented on issue #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494988010
 
 
   I have been commenting on the sibling issue - but I won't be able to help with how the struct is stored or modified on the c++ side.
   
   > I don't think there is anything wrong with setting the file_path in the footer metadata when there is a single file, or when all files are in the same directory.
   
   The thrift spec seems to indicate that you should not. An obvious problem, is that the existence of the path can be indicative that a file needs to be opened. Even if it's the same file, this can have an overhead.
   
   > It seems that this kind of nested file structure should be supported, so I think that this example disqualifies the solution I have implemented so far.
   
   Agreed, you cannot have both.

mrocklin commented on issue #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494995357
 
 
   From my perspective I don't see a reason to have the filename included in the metadata included in each file.  I'm alread at that file, presumably I don't need the filename any longer.  
   
   I do very much want the filename when I'm reading the `_metadata` file.  Actually, for large datasets on cloud-based systems, getting the filenames where all row groups live is critical.  Otherwise we have to do a listing on 10k objects, which can take a surprisingly long time.  
   
   Ideally when writing a partition, Arrow would do whatever is proper for footer metadata (I don't care about the file path here) but would return metadata objects to me in Python that had the appropriate file path set, or else would tell me the file path and the metadata and would provide me a mechanism to add the file path to the metadata.
   
   In cases where a single Python call writes many separate files (such as happening when partitioning) then I would probably expect to get many separate metadata objects, each with the file path appropriately set, or I would expect to get separate metadata objects and associated file paths, and it would be up to me to properly clean up the filepath (by truncating it or adding a root directory to it) and then assign it back into the metadata object as I wrote all of them to the metadata file.
   
   Does this make sense?  I *think* I've understood the concerns above, but I may be missing something.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

martindurant commented on issue #4361: ARROW-5349: [WIP] Store file-path metadata
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361#issuecomment-494996621
 
 
   > it would be up to me to properly clean up the filepath
   
   I would expect either
   - we get a filename back with the metadata piece, can work out what the path in the metadata object should be and call some method to set it, for each one or
   - the filenames in the metadata piece are correctly set by the writer and the outer layer doesn't do anything, which means the writer needs to know the root path.
   
   Note that these paths are always relative.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
After ARROW-5258 / https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4236 it is now possible to collect the file metadata while writing different files (then how to write those metadata was not yet addressed -> original issue ARROW-1983).

However, currently, the {{file_path}} information in the ColumnChunkMetaData object is not set. This is, I think, expected / correct for the metadata as included within the single file; but for using the metadata in the combined dataset `_metadata`, it needs a file path set.

So if you want to use this metadata for a partitioned dataset, there needs to be a way to specify this file path. 
Ideas I am thinking of currently: either, we could specify a file path to be used when writing, or expose the `set_file_path` method on the Python side so you can create an updated version of the metadata after collecting it.

cc [~pearu] [~mdurant]
fields.summary: [Python/C++] Provide a way to specify the file path in parquet ColumnChunkMetaData

comments.body:
There is an API available to set the file path

https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/parquet/metadata.h#L218

I would recommend adding a method on {{parquet::ParquetFileWriter}} that will set this attribute to a particular value for all column chunk metadata created. This method can be exposed then in Python

I submitted a WIP PR to address this issue ([https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4361]). 

Note that my background is limited in both C++ and Parquet, so the current solution is a bit messy.  I am happy to hear suggestions on a better approach.

[~mdurant] fastparquet only sets the file_path in the {{_metadata}} pooled metadata, and not in the metadata that is included in the footer of the file itself. Do you know if this is the common practice among other implementations that create such partitioned datasets?

No, I don't have an explicit reference for this, and I believe I got the original model from spark (i.e., presumably same as hive), which I suppose would make it "common" by itself. I think it's the only thing that makes sense, since each data file should be readable in isolation, and there would be no way of knowing it was part of a collection and that the paths should therefore be ignored. At a guess, the design of the standard may have foreseen data-only chunk files, without footer information.

Thanks. It is actually also quite clear in the thrift file description of {{file_path}}: "File where column data is stored.  If not set, assumed to be same file as metadata.  This path is relative to the current file."

Given that, for the API, it might make more sense to actually add a way to set the file path directly on the metadata object, instead of passing it to {{ParquetFileWriter}}. So that as a user of this API in python, you can set the path yourself on the metadata object that is returned by {{pq.ParquetWriter}} (which is appended to the metadata_collector).
Agreed on that last point, to let the caller set the path - if only because this is basically what fastparquet does.

> I think it's acceptable to set the path in the file's internal metadata.

 

A library loading that data file in isolation can (and maybe *should*) be confused by this, though. Maybe that would not be typical operation, but we shouldn't preclude it.

Okay - the file path should not be set in the footer metadata (only in _metadata).  Does this mean that a mechanism for setting the file_path in C++ is completely unnecessary?  My understanding is that the motivation for this issue was to populate the file_path for the following step of writing the metadata file.  Is it sufficient to add a python-only mechanism to set the path? Or should we leave it up to the user to modify the metadata object themselves?

It depends on what is passed back to the caller: just the metadata object, or some indication of which file it went into (sorry, I don't know the API that's being built exactly). If the caller defines which file to write to, it would seem reasonable to let it set this attribute on the metadata object before writing to `_metadata`. However, that might be muddied if partitioning is also happening upon write and you end up with multiple files for each piece.

>  in which this would be wrong if it is inside the file itself

 

Agreed, the path would be wrong. Even in the simpler case, above, you could say it was wrong based on the thrift template - and this could make sense, as it maybe implies opening a new file.

Summary of the resolution: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4386 resolves that one can set the file path on the FileMetadata object returned by the arrow parquet writers (through metadata_collector). Which means that a user of the python API (such as dask) can set the appropriate file path for the collected metadata objects before combining them.

For future reference, here is a small partitioned dataset written by PySpark:  [^test_pyspark_dataset.zip]
